articles.headline: G.O.P. Blocks Vote in Senate on Hagel for Defense Post
articles.snippet: The move to stall Chuck Hagel’s nomination for defense secretary was likely to worsen partisan tensions while keeping the White House from assembling its national security team.
articles.abstract: The move to stall Chuck Hagel’s nomination for defense secretary was likely to worsen partisan tensions while keeping the White House from assembling its national security team.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Thursday blocked President Obama’s nominee to lead the Pentagon in a defiant move likely to further strain partisan tensions while preventing the White House, at least temporarily, from assembling its second-term national security team.

articles.headline: Merck Settles Suits Over Cholesterol Drug
articles.snippet: The drug maker agreed to pay $688 million to settle two lawsuits that said it had harmed investors by delaying the release of unfavorable study results for a cholesterol drug.
articles.abstract: The drug maker agreed to pay $688 million to settle two lawsuits that said it had harmed investors by delaying the release of unfavorable study results for a cholesterol drug.
articles.lead_paragraph: Merck has agreed to pay $688 million to settle lawsuits claiming that it had harmed investors by delaying the release of unfavorable study results for its cholesterol drug Vytorin, the company announced on Thursday.

articles.headline: One Step Toward Rethinking Taxes
articles.snippet: A proposal by Dave Camp of the House Ways and Means Committee would change the way derivatives are taxed and the way capital gains are calculated.
articles.abstract: A proposal by Dave Camp of the House Ways and Means Committee would change the way derivatives are taxed and the way capital gains are calculated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tax reform, at least in American politics these days, is generally discussed at only the most abstract level. There is general agreement that it would be nice to lower tax rates while broadening the base by getting rid of loopholes. The latter, of course, are seldom specified in any detail, and are very much in the eye of the beholder.

articles.headline: Vows of Change in China Belie Private Warning
articles.snippet: Behind closed doors, Xi Jinping held up the Soviet Union’s collapse as the risk of wavering from traditional ideology.
articles.abstract: Behind closed doors, Xi Jinping held up the Soviet Union’s collapse as the risk of wavering from traditional ideology.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — When China’s new leader, Xi Jinping, visited the country’s south to promote himself before the public as an audacious reformer following in the footsteps of Deng Xiaoping, he had another message to deliver to Communist Party officials behind closed doors.

articles.headline: Service Cuts May Follow Merger of Airlines
articles.snippet: Some consumer advocates are warning that the merger of American Airlines and US Airways, if approved, could bring rising fees and fares as well as service cuts to smaller cities.
articles.abstract: Some consumer advocates are warning that the merger of American Airlines and US Airways, if approved, could bring rising fees and fares as well as service cuts to smaller cities.

articles.headline: Blackstone Keeps Most of Its Money With SAC
articles.snippet: The Blackstone Group said it would keep most of its $550 million with SAC Capital Advisors for three more months, as the hedge fund’s clients faced a regularly scheduled quarterly deadline on Thursday to decide whether to continue investing.
articles.abstract: The Blackstone Group said it would keep most of its $550 million with SAC Capital Advisors for three more months, as the hedge fund’s clients faced a regularly scheduled quarterly deadline on Thursday to decide whether to continue investing.

articles.headline: Confidence on Upswing, Mergers Make Comeback
articles.snippet: Bankers and lawyers warn that it is still too early to declare a mergers-and-acquisitions boom like those during the junk bond craze of 1989, the dot-com bubble of 1999 and the leveraged buyout bonanza of 2007.
articles.abstract: Bankers and lawyers warn that it is still too early to declare a mergers-and-acquisitions boom like those during the junk bond craze of 1989, the dot-com bubble of 1999 and the leveraged buyout bonanza of 2007.

articles.headline: Pittsburgh’s Time of Transition
articles.snippet: Pittsburgh has changed from an industrial city with many manufacturing jobs to a municipality with the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center as its largest employer.
articles.abstract: Pittsburgh has changed from an industrial city with many manufacturing jobs to a municipality with the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center as its largest employer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sprawling H. J. Heinz headquarters in Pittsburgh was turned into apartment lofts for the city’s growing creative class long ago. The famous five-story neon ketchup bottle that stood outside the headquarters has been moved to the wall of the city’s history museum.

articles.headline: San Diego Ex-Mayor Confronts $1 Billion Gambling Problem
articles.snippet: Maureen O’Connor blamed an addiction aggravated by a brain tumor for a gargantuan spree that she financed in part by taking from her husband’s charity.
articles.abstract: Maureen O’Connor blamed an addiction aggravated by a brain tumor for a gargantuan spree that she financed in part by taking from her husband’s charity.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A former mayor of San Diego spent the last decade wagering more than a billion dollars at casinos across the country, eventually liquidating her savings, auctioning her belongings, selling off real estate, borrowing from friends and taking more than $2 million from a charity set up by her late husband, a fast-food tycoon.

articles.headline: Shock Wave of Fireball Meteor Rattles Siberia, Injuring 1,200
articles.snippet: Scenes from a city rocked by a shock wave when a meteor hit the atmosphere offered a glimpse of an apocalyptic scenario that scientists said had never before hurt so many people.
articles.abstract: Scenes from a city rocked by a shock wave when a meteor hit the atmosphere offered a glimpse of an apocalyptic scenario that scientists said had never before hurt so many people.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Gym class came to a halt inside the Chelyabinsk Railway Institute, and students gathered around the window, gazing at the fat white contrail that arced its way across the morning sky. A missile? A comet? A few quiet moments passed. And then, with incredible force, the windows blew in.
articles.byline: By Ellen Barry and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: To Avoid Delay, Airbus Drops Lithium-Ion Batteries
articles.snippet: The problems Boeing is having with lithium-ion battery technology has led Airbus to change its plan, and use a conventional battery, made of nickel-cadmium.
articles.abstract: The problems Boeing is having with lithium-ion battery technology has led Airbus to change its plan, and use a conventional battery, made of nickel-cadmium.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to the volatile new lithium-ion battery technology, Boeing and Airbus are heading in different directions.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: It’s Scotch, but the Owners Live Elsewhere
articles.snippet: Scottish whisky distillers are weighing a “bottle tax” for companies outside the country that control about four-fifths of the global market for Scotch.
articles.abstract: Scottish whisky distillers are weighing a “bottle tax” for companies outside the country that control about four-fifths of the global market for Scotch.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALLINDALLOCH, SCOTLAND — George S. Grant markets malt whisky made in the shadow of the snow-capped Ben Rinnes, the same spot where, five generations ago, his family bought a distillery in 1865 for £511.
